encodingDesc.p: As students of English 478, Victoria Fultz and Hannah Cahill have chosen to encode and transcribe orginal documents written by or for Walt Whitman.

body.p: Since your departure some of my Chicago friends have presented me with certificates of character, they having known me many years. They said that they would do no hurt to have them with me.

I have also written to Samuel Deanin Salt Lake, for like certificate. I having employed with him in the Quartermaster Department as clerk, at the place. I also wrote to Webb & Brother, freighters in that place. They employed me when I first went into the country for several months, and knew my reputation while there.

I directed them to send the certificate to you at Ft. Bridger, thinking you would be likely to get them there, as I may
be taken west soon to recieve them here.
Mr. Yates came to day and took me out to visit my wife and som other friends. I think him very kind, and a perfect gentleman.
Stickneytold some of the prisoners that he had money enough to get him out of this scrape. Thouugh I do not fewar that he will accomplish what he effects to.

I have all the faith that any one possible could have in yourself and Mr. Yates, and thinkg that I shall have justice done, and come home exhonoratedexoneratedfrom all blame, for God knows that the thought of committing a wicked crime was never in my heart. Words would not induce me to do anything that would brakebreaka wife's heart and bring any aged mother in sorrow to her grave. Pray excuse me for writing such sentiments but I cannot help it.
Allow me to thank youu for the kind interest you have manifested, for which I shall be indebted to you.
Any word from you will gladly be recieved through Mr. Yatesat this place.
body.closer:
With Respect
Your obedient servant George W. Black
body.note: George W. Black and M.S. Stickney were accused of murdering a Mr. Bicking on Octoberr 19th 1866 while all three men were traveling together near Salt Lake City. Black at the time of writing this letter had been detained in the Cook County Jail in Chicago, but would later be released in March of 1867 despite pleading guilty.
